fields.description:
Researchers at the University of Cambridge reported a vulnerability affecting Fisheye and Crucible where special characters, known as Unicode bidirectional override characters, are not rendered or displayed in the affected applications. These special characters are typically not displayed by the browser or code editors but can affect the meaning of the source code when it is processed by a compiler or an interpreter. The issue is now fixed.

*Affected versions:*
 * Crucible
 ** All versions before 4.8.8

 * Fisheye
 ** All versions before 4.8.8

*Fixed versions:*
 * Crucible
 ** 4.8.8

 * Fisheye
 ** 4.8.8

*References:*
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/security/multiple-products-security-advisory-unrendered-unicode-bidirectional-override-characters-cve-2021-42574-1086419475.html
fields.summary: Unicode characters allow malicious code to be hidden from a human reviewer (Fisheye & Crucible) - CVE-2021-42574

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

In FIsheye 4.8.7 we use javax.mail-1.6.2.jar to support TLS1.2 for mail. Due to dependencies from other packages, mail-1.4.jar is still included and can cause issues with sending mail if not explicitly removed.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure SMTP in Fisheye with the option *Use SSL/TLS*=true
 # Send a test mail using a mail server that does not support TLS1.0,1.1 (such as Office365)

h3. Expected Results

Mail gets sent successfully
h3. Actual Results

Test mail fails

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-fisheye.log file:
{noformat}
nested exception is:
    	javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: No appropriate protocol (protocol is disabled or cipher suites are inappropriate)
	at com.sun.mail.smtp.SMTPTransport.sendCommand(SMTPTransport.java:1420) [mail-1.4.jar:1.4]
	at com.sun.mail.smtp.SMTPTransport.sendCommand(SMTPTransport.java:1408) [mail-1.4.jar:1.4]
	at com.sun.mail.smtp.SMTPTransport.ehlo(SMTPTransport.java:847) [mail-1.4.jar:1.4]
	at com.sun.mail.smtp.SMTPTransport.protocolConnect(SMTPTransport.java:384) [mail-1.4.jar:1.4]
{noformat}
In this case, the mail-1.4.jar was picked up, instead of the correct 1.6.2. Since mail-1.4 does not support TLS1.2, the exception _No appropriate protocol (protocol is disabled or cipher suites are inappropriate)_ is thrown
h3. Workaround
 * Remove mail-1.4.jar from $FISHEYE_INSTALLATION/lib
 * Restart Fisheye
fields.summary: Remove mail-1.4.jar to prevent issues with TLS 1.2

When an adminisitrator is logged in using administration password and not as the admin user, it's not possible to open the ATST (Atlassian Troubleshooting and Support Tools) page. It redirects to a login form.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Log in using administration password (a link from the page footer).
 # Open Settings > System Settings > Tr[oubleshooting and support tools.|https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/plugins/servlet/troubleshooting/view/]

h3. Expected Results

A page is opened.
h3. Actual Results

A user is redirected to a login page.
h3. Workaround

Log in as admin user (login/password).
fields.summary: Opening the ATST plugin page when logged in using administration password redirects to a login page

fields.description:
h3. Problem

In some circumstances it may happen that a search for file paths (e.g. when user uses a quick search box) is very resource intensive in Fisheye. This can result in CPU saturation, high heap memory consumption or even OOME error leading to application crash.

This is caused by a fact that file paths are being searched for both the exact string entered by a user as well as for a camel-case pattern. For example, entering a text "ABCc" Fisheye can find files like "ABCc.java" as well as "AaaaBbbbCccc.java". In order to find camel-case matches, Fisheye extracts all terms matching given prefixes. This might result in a very complex Lucene query constructed when there are many matches (tens of thousands).

Note: a search is performed in a cross-repository Lucene index (globalfe/idx0).

h3. Symptoms

1. Search for file paths takes seconds or minutes instead of miliseconds, see the TTFB on the network activity in a browser. Example:

 !quick-search-file-paths.png|thumbnail! 

2. High heap consumption. Heap dumps shows large amounts of data allocated in qtp-* threads and occupied by Lucene classes. Example:

 !quick-search-heap-dump.png|thumbnail! 

3. High CPU activity.


h3. Suggested solution

Add a [JVM fisheye|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/jvm-system-properties-960155689.html] property which will allow to disable camel-case search for file paths.
fields.summary: Add an option to disable camel-case search for file paths

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
fisheyectl.bat loads aways FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml instead of FISHEYE_INST/config.xml even though all the env variables are correctly set.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# With {{set}} command check that FISHEYE_HOME and FISHEYE_INST are set to the correct locations
# Use {{setx}} to correct it if neccessary
# Try executing fisheyectl.bat with svnrules, byteman or scannow
{code}
C:\Atlassian\fecru-4.8.6\bin\fisheyectl.bat svnrules myrsvnrepo
{code}

h3. Expected Results
The command executed and produced the output
h3. Actual Results
The command fails to execute and an error is shown: "ERROR - Could not find a Fisheye or Crucible license."

From the console output, you can observe that it always using FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml:
{code}
WARN: your default encoding (windows-1252) does not support unicode.
This is likely to cause problems if any of the filenames, branch names or tag names in one of your repositories contain unicode characters.
Update your locale settings or start with the -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 option to avoid these problems.
INFO  - Using log4j configuration file: C:\Atlassian\fecru-4.8.6\log4j-client.xml
INFO  - Fisheye SVN Symbolic Rules Verifier
INFO  - Fisheye arguments: [myrsvnrepo]
INFO  - loading config from file: C:\Atlassian\fecru-4.8.6\config.xml
ERROR - Could not find a Fisheye or Crucible license.
{code}
h3. Workaround
# Rename FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml to FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml_old
# Copy FISHEYE_INST/config.xml to FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml
# Execute the script once again
fields.summary: fisheyectl.bat on Windows loads always FISHEYE_HOME/config.xml instead of FISHEYE_INST/config.xml

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Jira's Development Panel executes the *{{/rest/remote-link-aggregation/latest/aggregation}}* REST API endpoint against Fisheye, however the number of Jira issues requiring an update is potentially infinite.

Due to that, the response URL sent by Fisheye may be too large, resulting in {{*HTTP status 414 URI Too Long*}} errors in Jira side.

Even though there is a workaround (see below), it fixes the issue just temporarily. If Fisheye continues to send larger and larger URL's, with time it will exceed again the URL length allowed by the workaround, so customers may face this problem over and over, and this is the main problem.

Just like Bitbucket has the property *{{plugin.jira-development-integration.issues.updated.max}}* for controlling the max fetch size (which fixes the issue once and forever), there should be a similar solution for Fisheye. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Integrate Jira with Fisheye
 # Make sure that a Jira issues have commits associated to them
 # Either wait until Jira requests an update automatically or execute {{GET}} against {{<fisheye_url>/rest/remote-link-aggregation/latest/aggregation}}:

7392&globalId=TEST8-850&globalId=TEST4-110&globalId=TEST2-18537&globalId=TEST5-1784&globalId=TEST1-723&globalId=TEST-7217&globalId=TEST3-7217&globalId=TEST7-497&globalId=TEST-7219&globalId=TEST3-7219&globalId=TEST-7221&globalId=TEST3-7221&globalId=TEST16-560&globalId=TEST17-560&globalId=TEST18-560&globalId=TEST2-14638&globalId=TEST2-13347&globalId=TEST2-18539&globalId=TEST5-2801&globalId=TEST2-15809&globalId=TEST5-1787&globalId=TEST2-18543&globalId=TEST2-17403&globalId=TEST-4939&globalId=TEST3-4939&globalId=TEST8-853&globalId=TEST5-1789&globalId=TEST5-1790&globalId=TEST-5624&globalId=TEST3-5624&globalId=TEST14-553&globalId=TEST-6333&globalId=TEST3-6333&globalId=TEST2-17408&globalId=TEST5-2376&globalId=TEST2-18043&globalId=TEST5-2378&globalId=TEST2-17409&globalId=TEST6-1093&globalId=TEST2-17413&globalId=TEST-7314&globalId=TEST3-7314&globalId=TEST2-13391&globalId=TEST-6626&globalId=TEST3-6626&globalId=TEST5-1322&globalId=TEST-6341&globalId=TEST3-6341&globalId=TEST7-552&globalId=TEST5-2814&globalId=TEST1-466&globalId=TEST-6344&globalId=TEST3-6344&globalId=TEST2-16768&globalId=TEST10-1323&globalId=TEST11-1323&globalId=TEST5-1796&globalId=TEST5-1797&globalId=TEST4-328&globalId=TEST-7070&globalId=TEST3-7070&globalId=TEST2-18049&globalId=TEST2-14716&globalId=TEST5-2826&globalId=TEST2-15876&globalId=TEST2-15883&globalId=TEST5-620&globalId=TEST5-2836&globalId=TEST5-2837&globalId=TEST5-1812&globalId=TEST1-724&globalId=TEST4-223&globalId==TEST12-394&globalId==TEST12-395&globalId==TEST12-396&globalId==TEST12-401&globalId==TEST12-404&globalId=TEST2-15897&globalId=TEST5-1818&globalId=TEST5-1820&globalId=TEST2-13450&globalId=TEST5-2397&globalId=TEST2-16792&globalId=TEST5-2398&globalId=TEST5-2399&globalId=TEST5-2400&globalId=TEST-241&globalId=TEST3-241&globalId=TEST5-2401&globalId=TEST-4626&globalId=TEST3-4626&globalId=TEST4-256&globalId=TEST2-18053&globalId=TEST1-500&globalId=TEST7-269&globalId=TEST7-500&globalId=TEST8-792&globalId=TEST2-18055&globalId=TEST5-1842&globalId=TEST5-1843&globalId=TEST14-611&globalId=TEST2-18057&globalId=TEST5-1848&globalId=TEST5-2404&globalId=TEST-7087&globalId=TEST3-7087&globalId=TEST4-257&globalId=TEST-4232&globalId=TEST3-4232&globalId=TEST1-665&globalId=TEST2-18062&globalId=TEST6-1031&globalId=TEST2-18063&globalId=TEST6-1105&globalId=TEST2-18065&globalId=TEST5-1855&globalId=TEST6-1108&globalId=TEST5-1856&globalId=TEST5-1857&globalId=TEST2-18069&globalId=TEST-7088&globalId=TEST3-7088&globalId=TEST-1108&globalId=TEST3-1108&globalId=TEST-7089&globalId=TEST3-7089&globalId=TEST5-2868&globalId=TEST8-550&globalId=TEST7-379&globalId==TEST12-793&globalId=TEST5-1863&globalId=TEST14-431&globalId=TEST5-1864&globalId=TEST7-506&globalId=TEST7-507&globalId=TEST5-2870&globalId=TEST5-1865&globalId=TEST7-270&globalId=TEST5-2872&globalId=TEST5-2873&globalId=TEST2-16834&globalId=TEST2-18080&globalId=TEST5-2408&"
{code}
 # The URL is too large, resulting in {{*HTTP status 414 URI Too Long*}} in Jira's development panel

h3. Expected Results

The {{*HTTP status 414 URI Too Long*}} error should not happen in Jira side anymore once there is a setting for controlling the max fetch size.

Just like Bitbucket has the property *{{plugin.jira-development-integration.issues.updated.max}}* for controlling the max fetch size (which fixes the issue once and forever), there should be a similar solution for Fisheye. 
h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown in the Jira log file :
{noformat}
2021-03-02 11:37:16,948-0500 Caesium-1-2 ERROR ServiceRunner [c.a.j.p.devstatus.provider.DefaultDevSummaryPollService] Refresh failure
com.atlassian.jira.plugin.devstatus.provider.DataProviderRefreshFailure: Data Provider [Id: 6f5b2efa-c2c5-3bfa-a6e4-c711f8e01feb, Type: fecru] refresh failed with error code 414 and message - HTTP status 414 URI Too Long]'
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Set the {{jetty.http.requestHeaderSize}} [system property|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/jvm-system-properties-960155689.html] with a value higher than the default of 8192 bytes and restart Fisheye.
fields.summary: Remote Link Aggregation API may send extremely large URLs to Jira causing 414 issues

fields.description:
When using FeCru REST APIs, if the name of the object, such as permission scheme, contains a slash character ( / ), then the call will fail with 404, even if the slash is replaced with its URL encoded character(s).

The suggestion here is to either:
- support slash (or its URL encoded character) in the REST API
- add support for object IDs, rather than names, in the REST API
- ensure an object cannot be created with a slash in its name

(i) The last option is based off current workaround of renaming the object without the slash in the name.
fields.summary: Slash character is not supported in REST API URLs

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Users may get an email with subject "Tips and tricks for Fisheye", just like this one I've received:
 !image-2021-03-03-18-21-10-779.png|width=616,height=487! 
 The URL on "Learn more" button is this one below, and it takes you to a dead link:

[https://click.e.atlassian.com/?qs=5f2c391144d4a126fe46fd3e57d4ec5768292191228deb36b74f7b9f86e77a8cc32d7ff9c7cf1520fdd0a5eeb8e2cc98974ec209c2d11461|https://click.e.atlassian.com/?qs=5f2c391144d4a126fe46fd3e57d4ec5768292191228deb36b74f7b9f86e77a8cc32d7ff9c7cf1520fdd0a5eeb8e2cc98974ec209c2d11461]

Clicking this takes you to:
 [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/using-side-by-side-diff-view-298976810.html?utm_source=eval-email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fisheye-server&utm_content=day-3]

The URL [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/using-side-by-side-diff-view-298976810.html] is invalid, as it should be this instead:

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/using-side-by-side-diff-view-960155326.html]

The numbers at the end of the URL are different, resulting in a dead link.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Receive the email "Tips and tricks for Fisheye" that talk about using the side-by-side diff.
 # Click "Learn more"

h3. Expected Results

Clicking "Learn more" should take the user to [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/using-side-by-side-diff-view-960155326.html]
h3. Actual Results

Clicking "Learn more" is taking the user to [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/using-side-by-side-diff-view-298976810.html], resulting in a dead link.
h3. Workaround

Search for "Using side by side diff" in Google, and it will be the first result.
fields.summary: Broken link in email notification

fields.description:
It would be good for FishEye/Crucible to auto rescan when the changelist description is re-edited rather than manually triggering rescan from the FishEye administration.

It is already possible to request a rescan via REST: [https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fecru.html#rest-service-fecru:admin:repositories:name:rescan-metadata] or Repository Admin UI

The disadvantage of this REST API is that it can only be called by Repository administrators. As a result it's not so useful for our users to fix this issue by themselves.

 
Thanks,

Yuanquan
fields.summary: Auto Reindex When Submitted Changelist Description Is Re-Edited In Perforce

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The WADL generator can't read the atlassian-plugin.xml file from bundled plugin jar. This is caused by the following bug in the Atlassian REST app:

* https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/REST-423

The bug was fixed on version *3.5.1* of the app. Fisheye/Crucible 4.8.6 ships with version *3.4.15*.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start Fisheye/Crucible.

h3. Expected Results
Fisheye/Crucible start up doesn't throw errors.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When Fisheye attempts to evaluate the applicable directories for a crowd SSO integration, it will still attempt to make calls to/parse disabled Crowd directories.

This can result in a very large amount of ERROR log entries flooding the application logs if the disabled Crowd directory is no longer reachable by Fisheye.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Link Fisheye to 2 different Crowd user directories
 # Enable [the SSO Crowd integration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/connecting-to-crowd-960155581.html#ConnectingtoCrowd-Singlesign-on(SSO)withCrowd] within Fisheye
 # Disable one of the two directories
 # Break the connection to the disabled directory (such as shutting down the Crowd instance or breaking its domain's DNS resolution on the Fisheye server)

h3. Expected Results

The disabled directory isn't pulled in/considered when Fisheye attempts to resolve an SSO-applicable request, and no error is thrown within the logs.

h3. Actual Results

All directories of type Crowd, regardless of their status, are pulled in:

{code:java}
    private List<Directory> getAllCrowdDirectories() {
        return crowdDirectoryService.findAllDirectories()
                .stream()
                .filter(directory -> directory.getType() == DirectoryType.CROWD)
                .collect(Collectors.toList());
    }
{code}

As a result, the inactive directory is called when resolving its cookie configuration, resulting in the following error if the crowd instance is unreachable:

{noformat}
2021-02-09 11:50:39,071 ERROR [REDACTED ] fisheye DefaultRemoteDirectoryService-isSSOSupportedBy - [Crowd SSO] Failed to get cookie configuration for directory: Old and Busted Crowd Server. Error: java.net.UnknownHostException: oldandbusted.crowdinstance.com
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: java.net.UnknownHostException: oldandbusted.crowdinstance.com
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestExecutor$MethodExecutor.andReceive(RestExecutor.java:425) [crowd-integration-client-rest-2.9.5-7fb674b.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.getCookieConfiguration(RestCrowdClient.java:1227) [crowd-integration-client-rest-2.9.5-7fb674b.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.sso.cookie.CachedCookieConfigurationService$1.getCookieConfiguration(CachedCookieConfigurationService.java:76) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.sso.cookie.CachedCookieConfigurationService$1.load(CachedCookieConfigurationService.java:105) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.sso.cookie.CachedCookieConfigurationService$1.load(CachedCookieConfigurationService.java:64) [fisheye.jar:?]
	[TRIMMED BY ATLASSIAN SUPPORT]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.sso.cookie.CachedCookieConfigurationService.getCookieConfigurationForDirectory(CachedCookieConfigurationService.java:122) [fisheye.jar:?]
	[TRIMMED BY ATLASSIAN SUPPORT]
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy154.getCookieConfigurationForDirectory(Unknown Source) [?:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.sso.authenticator.DefaultRemoteDirectoryService.isSSOSupportedBy(DefaultRemoteDirectoryService.java:92) [fisheye.jar:?]
	[TRIMMED BY ATLASSIAN SUPPORT]
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy155.isSSOSupportedBy(Unknown Source) [?:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.sso.DefaultEmbeddedCrowdSSOService.createCrowdDirectoriesByTokeName(DefaultEmbeddedCrowdSSOService.java:219) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.sso.DefaultEmbeddedCrowdSSOService.findPotentialSSODirectoriesForRequest(DefaultEmbeddedCrowdSSOService.java:161) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.sso.DefaultEmbeddedCrowdSSOService.getUserFromToken(DefaultEmbeddedCrowdSSOService.java:156) [fisheye.jar:?]
	[TRIMMED BY ATLASSIAN SUPPORT]
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy156.getUserFromToken(Unknown Source) [?:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.embeddedcrowd.DefaultEmbeddedCrowdAuth.getToken(DefaultEmbeddedCrowdAuth.java:101) [fisheye.jar:?]
	[TRIMMED BY ATLASSIAN SUPPORT]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.tryRequestDelegatedLogin(DefaultUserManager.java:609) [fisheye.jar:?]
	[TRIMMED BY ATLASSIAN SUPPORT]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.web.security.DefaultUserDetector.tryRequestDelegatedLogin(DefaultUserDetector.java:152) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.web.security.DefaultUserDetector.getUser(DefaultUserDetector.java:94) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.web.security.DefaultUserDetector.process(DefaultUserDetector.java:69) [fisheye.jar:?]
	[TRIMMED BY ATLASSIAN SUPPORT]
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748) [?:1.8.0_232]
Caused by: java.net.UnknownHostException: oldandbusted.crowdinstance.com
	[TRIMMED BY ATLASSIAN SUPPORT]
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestExecutor$MethodExecutor.executeCrowdServiceMethod(RestExecutor.java:574) [crowd-integration-client-rest-2.9.5-7fb674b.jar:?]
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestExecutor$MethodExecutor.andReceive(RestExecutor.java:413) [crowd-integration-client-rest-2.9.5-7fb674b.jar:?]
	... 182 more
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

* Export the existing directory configuration as a backup, and then remove the inactive Crowd directory causing the error
* [Disable the SSO integration with Crowd|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/connecting-to-crowd-960155581.html#ConnectingtoCrowd-Singlesign-on(SSO)withCrowd]
* Resolve the connection issue such that the disabled directory continues to resolve to an active crowd instance
fields.summary: Crowd SSO integration attempts to retrieve cookie configuration for disabled crowd directories

fields.description:
Affected versions of Atlassian FishEye and Crucible allow remote attackers to view sensitive information via an Information Disclosure vulnerability in a vulnerable version of the Application Links component.

The affected versions are before version 4.8.6.

*Affected versions:*
 * version < 4.8.6

*Fixed versions:*
 * 4.8.6
fields.summary: Update application links to 5.4.23 to fix CVE-2020-5398

fields.description:
Affected versions of Atlassian Fisheye and Crucible allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to achieve remote code execution, denial of service and XML external entities in Atlassian Gadgets. The CVEs involved were:
 * CVE-2012-0881
 * CVE-2019-10172
 * CVE-2018-1000632
 * CVE-2016-1000031
 * CVE-2014-0114
 * CVE-2020-26217

The affected versions are before version 4.8.6.

*Affected versions:*
 * version < 4.8.6

*Fixed versions:*
 * 4.8.6
fields.summary: Update atlassian-gadgets to 4.2.39 to fix CVE-2012-0881, CVE-2014-0114 and other vulnerabilities

fields.description:
Update Atlassian Platform from 3.5.17 to 3.5.19. The new platform version brings changes in the following libraries:
 * update com.atlassian.applinks:* from 5.4.21 to 5.4.23
 * update com.atlassian.plugins:* from 4.4.10 to 4.4.14
 * update com.atlassian.sal:* from 3.1.2 to 3.1.3
 * update com.atlassian.streams:* from 6.3.4 to 6.3.5

 

Vulnerabilities fixed in Atlassian Platform 3.5.19:
 * [CVE-2019-17571|https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-17571] (removed unnecessary log4j dependency)
 * [CVE-2020-5398|https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-5398] (updated spring-web)
 * [CVE-2020-13956|https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-13956] (updated httpclient)
 * [CVE-2018-1000613|https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-1000613] (removed bouncycastle dependency)
fields.summary: Update Atlassian Platform to 3.5.19 to fix CVE-2018-1000613, CVE-2019-17571 and other vulnerabilities

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If a Jira issue was moved between projects and a Perforce changelist happens to include both issue keys (old and new) the number of commits associated to that issue is counted twice.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
{panel:title=|borderStyle=dashed|borderColor=#6a8eb3|titleBGColor=#f8f8f8|bgColor=#f8f8f8}
You must have Jira and Fisheye/Crucible connected using AppLinks to reproduce this problem.
{panel}
# Add a Perforce repository to Fisheye/Crucible. Let's call the repository *Perforce1*.
# Create a new Jira issue e.g. FORCE-1
# Submit changelist to *Perforce1* including "FORCE-1" in the comments.
# Once the changelist/ commit starts showing up inside your Jira issue, look for the following in the database:
{code:sql}
select *
  from "AO_575BF5_DEV_SUMMARY"
 where "JSON" like '%FORCE-1%';
{code}
||CREATED||ID||ISSUE_ID||JSON||PROVIDER_SOURCE_ID||UPDATED||
|2021-01-26 17:07:03|11|10101|\{"value":\{"targets":\{"FORCE-1":\[\{"type":\{"id":"repository"},"objects":\[\{"lastUpdated":"2021-01-26T17:06:59.000+0000","count":1,"commits":\["3"],"type":"p4"}]},\{"type":\{"id":"review"},"objects":\[]},\{"type":\{"id":"branch"},"objects":\[]}]}},"expiry":9223371721494775807}|d4cbcfce-60db-3178-960d-311f3240cdd5|2021-01-26 17:07:09|
# Now move FORCE-1 to a new project e.g. THANOS-7.
# Submit a new changelist to *Perforce1* including "THANOS-7" in the comments.
# Let's look inside the Jira database again:
||CREATED||ID||ISSUE_ID||JSON||PROVIDER_SOURCE_ID||UPDATED||
|2021-01-26 17:07:03|11|10101|\{"value":\{"targets":\{"THANOS-7":\[\{"type":\{"id":"repository"},"objects":\[\{"lastUpdated":"2021-01-26T17:09:50.000+0000","count":1,"commits":\["4"],"type":"p4"}]},\{"type":\{"id":"review"},"objects":\[]},\{"type":\{"id":"branch"},"objects":\[]}],"FORCE-1":\[\{"type":\{"id":"repository"},"objects":\[\{"lastUpdated":"2021-01-26T17:06:59.000+0000","count":1,"commits":\["3"],"type":"p4"}]},\{"type":\{"id":"review"},"objects":\[]},\{"type":\{"id":"branch"},"objects":\[]}]}},"expiry":9223371721494775807}|d4cbcfce-60db-3178-960d-311f3240cdd5|2021-01-26 17:10:03|
# So far, so good. There are 2 unique changelists associated to that Jira issue inside the database and the *Development* panel is telling us there are 2 commits linked to it.
# {color:red}Now, submit a new changelist containing THANOS-7 and FORCE-1.{color}

h3. Expected Results

The *Development* panel should display 3 *unique* changelists/ commits associated to your Jira issue.

h3. Actual Results

The *Development* panel is now reporting 4 commits associated to my issue when there's in fact only 3 *unique* commits. The following message is displayed when expanding/ clicking the commits in Jira:

{quote}
You don't have access to view all related commits. Please contact your administrator.
{quote}

The *Development* panel displays the details of 3 commits (this is accurate) but it says there are 4 commits (wrong) and we don't have access to see all of them.

Let's look again inside the Jira database:

||CREATED||ID||ISSUE_ID||JSON||PROVIDER_SOURCE_ID||UPDATED||
|2021-01-26 17:07:03|11|10101|\{"value":\{"targets":\{"THANOS-7":\[\{"type":\{"id":"repository"},"objects":\[\{"lastUpdated":"2021-01-26T17:13:28.000+0000","count":2,"commits":\["4","5"],"type":"p4"}]},\{"type":\{"id":"review"},"objects":\[]},\{"type":\{"id":"branch"},"objects":\[]}],"FORCE-1":\[\{"type":\{"id":"repository"},"objects":\[\{"lastUpdated":"2021-01-26T17:13:28.000+0000","count":2,"commits":\["5","3"],"type":"p4"}]},\{"type":\{"id":"review"},"objects":\[]},\{"type":\{"id":"branch"},"objects":\[]}]}},"expiry":9223371721494775807}|d4cbcfce-60db-3178-960d-311f3240cdd5|2021-01-26 17:14:03|

Changelist *5* is showing up twice for THANOS-7 and FORCE-1. The *Development* panel should be able to tell them apart and identify *unique* commits only.

h3. Workaround

# Modify/ edit the changelist that includes multiple keys of the same Jira issue {{p4 change -i -u}} and remove one of the keys.
# Access the *Fisheye admin > Repositories > P4REPOSITORY > Maintenance* page and click *Re-index*.
#* A re-index of the repository is necessary because the changelist you're modifying had already been indexed by Fisheye/Crucible.
# Submit a new changelist and associate it to your issue to force Jira to update the database record for it.
# From this moment on the *Development* panel will display the correct number of changelists/ commits associated to your Jira issue.

h3. Notes

This issue was tested against Perforce and Git repositories. It does not affect Git commits, only Perforce changelists.
fields.summary: Adding multiple Jira issue keys to Perforce changelists may cause Jira to display incorrect number of commits associated to an issue

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
If there is a timeout detected during startup there will be a banner in the UI mentioning the timeout. As per our resource the only way to clear this banner is to restart the application which will clear the banner if there is not timeout detect during the subsequent startup process: https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/fisheye-timeoutexception-after-20000ms-banner-753436420.html

Restarting the application may not be possible if a change/maintenance window must be scheduled as per required business processes. This means that the banner will be displayed until the next change/maintenance window which could be days or months.

h3. Suggested Solution
 - Document either a way to remove the banner without restarting the application or add information to that resource that contains the rationale for not providing such an option.

h3. Workaround 
- This message is produced by our bundled fecru-healthsource-plugin. As a workaround the plugin can be disabled until the instance can be restarted.
fields.summary: As a user I want to clear the startup timeout banner without restarting Fisheye

fields.description:
In case of large commits (about 40MB of 'hg felog' output), performance of 'hg felog' command (which is a custom plugin for Mercurial, shipped with Fisheye) can be one magnitude slower than built-in 'hg log' + 'hg diff' commands. As a result, repository indexing is slow. 

Example results:

 !hg-felog-hg-log-hg-diff.png|thumbnail! 

Script:

{code}
REPO=<repository name>
HASH=<commit hash>
FISHEYE_DIR=<installation dir>

cd $FISHEYE_INST/var/cache/$REPO/clone

for I in {1..10}; do
    echo "Execution #$I"

    echo "Running hg felog ..."
    time /usr/bin/hg --config extensions.felog=$FISHEYE_DIR/python/hg/hgfelog/hgfelog.py --config ui.verbose=false felog $HASH -p -m 1>/dev/null

    echo "Running hg log ..."    
    time hg log -v -r $HASH 1>/dev/null

    echo "Running hg diff ..."
    time hg diff --git -c $HASH 1>/dev/null

done > hg-timings.log 2>&1 
{code}

Expected:

Improve performance of 'felog' to reach speed similar to original Mercurial commands.
fields.summary: Improve performance of 'hg felog' command used for indexing of Mercurial repositories

fields.description:
Affected version of Atlassian Fisheye/Crucible allow remote attackers to achieve Regex Denial of Service via user-supplied regex in EyeQL.

The affected versions are before version 4.8.4. 

*Affected versions:*
 * version < 4.8.4

*Fixed versions:*
 * 4.8.4
 * 4.9.0
fields.summary: A user-supplied regex in EyeQL causes ReDoS - CVE-2020-14190

fields.description:
Affected versions of Atlassian Fisheye and Crucible allow remote attackers to view a product's SEN via an Information Disclosure vulnerability in the x-asen response header from Atlassian Analytics.

The affected versions are before version 4.8.4.

*Affected versions:*
 * version < 4.8.4

*Fixed versions:*
 * 4.8.4
fields.summary: Information disclosure of product SEN via the x-asen response header - CVE-2020-14192

fields.description:
Affected versions of Atlassian Fisheye/Crucible allow remote attackers to impact the application's availability via a Denial of Service (DoS) vulnerability in the MessageBundleResource within Atlassian Gadgets.

The affected versions are before version 4.8.4.

*Affected versions:*

 * version < 4.8.4

*Fixed versions:*

 * 4.8.4
 * 4.9.0
fields.summary: DoS vulnerability in MessageBundleResource - CVE-2020-14191

fields.description:
Affected versions of Atlassian FishEye/Crucible allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via a Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability via an unintentional expression in Freemarker tags, in Apache Struts.

The affected versions are before version 4.8.4.

*Affected versions:*

 * version < 4.8.4

*Fixed versions:*

 * 4.8.4
 * 4.9.0
fields.summary: Remote Code Execution attack via unintentional expression in Freemarker tag - CVE-2017-12611

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

It would be nice to change the command used to test connection against Mercurial repositories to prevent a (false-positive) timeout during the repository set up. Fisheye is currently cloning the first changeset 0 in the Mercurial repository to a temporary folder in order to validate/ test the connection:
{noformat}
hg --config ui.verbose=false clone -r 0 -e "/atlassian/apps/fisheye/bin/fe-ssh.sh" --noupdate ssh://your-mercurial-server/repository /atlassian/data/fisheye/var/tmp/hg_test_clone_1605702252133
{noformat}
This works fine most part of the time unless the first changeset in the repository is big and takes over 60 seconds to clone. There's 60-second timeout imposed by Fisheye in the test connection process.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Connect to a Mercurial repository with a relatively big changeset # 0 (e.g. 10000 files added).
 # Configure a Mercurial repository inside Fisheye and attempt a connection test.

h3. Expected Results

Connection is successful because you are able to connect to the repository.
h3. Actual Results

Test connection fails with the following errors:
{noformat}
2020-11-18 12:24:12,145 DEBUG [qtp2073640037-375 xxx] fisheye DvcsProcessMonitor-onBeforeStart - Starting process: hg --config ui.verbose=false clone -r 0 -e "/atlassian/apps/fisheye/bin/fe-ssh.sh" --noupdate ssh://... /atlassian/data/fisheye/var/tmp/hg_test_clone_1605702252133
2020-11-18 12:25:12,254 DEBUG [qtp2073640037-375 xxx] fisheye DvcsProcessMonitor-onAfterFinished - Finished process: hg --config ui.verbose=false clone -r 0 -e "/atlassian/apps/fisheye/bin/fe-ssh.sh" --noupdate ssh://... /atlassian/data/fisheye/var/tmp/hg_test_clone_1605702252133 took 60109ms
...
2020-11-18 12:25:14,927 WARN  [qtp2073640037-375 xxx] fisheye IOHelper-recursiveDeleteImpl - problem deleting directory /atlassian/data/fisheye/var/tmp/hg_test_clone_1605702252133/.hg/store/data/...
...
2020-11-18 12:25:14,966 ERROR [qtp2073640037-375 xxx] fisheye RepositoryAdminRpcServiceImpl-testRepositoryConnection - Error testing connection.

com.atlassian.fisheye.spi.admin.services.RepositoryConfigException: com.cenqua.fisheye.config.ConfigException: Error talking to repository:

        at com.atlassian.fisheye.spi.admin.impl.DefaultRepositoryAdminService.testConnectionFor(DefaultRepositoryAdminService.java:966) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) [?:1.8.0_265]
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62) [?:1.8.0_265]
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) [?:1.8.0_265]
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498) [?:1.8.0_265]
        at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:317) [spring-aop-4.0.9.RELEASE.jar:4.0.9.RELEASE]
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:190) [spring-aop-4.0.9.RELEASE.jar:4.0.9.RELEASE]
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:157) [spring-aop-4.0.9.RELEASE.jar:4.0.9.RELEASE]
        at org.springframework.aop.aspectj.MethodInvocationProceedingJoinPoint.proceed(MethodInvocationProceedingJoinPoint.java:85) [spring-aop-4.0.9.RELEASE.jar:4.0.9.RELEASE]
        at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.WithSessionAspect.doCloseSession(WithSessionAspect.java:56) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor146.invoke(Unknown Source) [?:?]
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) [?:1.8.0_265]
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498) [?:1.8.0_265]
        ...
Caused by: com.cenqua.fisheye.config.ConfigException: Error talking to repository:


        at com.atlassian.fisheye.hg.HgScmConfig.testConnection(HgScmConfig.java:131) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.RepositoryConfig.testConnection(RepositoryConfig.java:390) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.spi.admin.impl.DefaultRepositoryAdminService.testConnectionFor(DefaultRepositoryAdminService.java:964) [fisheye.jar:?]
        ... 186 more
Caused by: com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessException: While executing: "hg --config ui.verbose=false clone -r 0 -e "/atlassian/apps/fisheye/bin/fe-ssh.sh" --noupdate ssh://... /atlassian/data/fisheye/var/tmp/hg_test_clone_1605702252133"
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.dvcs.DvcsScmConfig.executeCommand(DvcsScmConfig.java:142) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.hg.HgScmConfig.testConnection(HgScmConfig.java:125) [fisheye.jar:?]
        ... 188 more
Caused by: com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessTimeoutException: process timed out
        at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcessImpl.wrapUpProcess(ExternalProcessImpl.java:506) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcessImpl.finish(ExternalProcessImpl.java:423) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcessImpl.execute(ExternalProcessImpl.java:378) [atlassian-processutils-1.5.14.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.dvcs.DvcsScmConfig.executeCommand(DvcsScmConfig.java:139) [fisheye.jar:?]
        ... 189 more
2020-11-18 12:25:15,004 ERROR [qtp2073640037-375 xxx] fisheye RepositoryAdminRpcServiceImpl-testRepositoryConnection - Connection failed.
{noformat}

h3. Notes

This does not affect the indexing process for Mercurial repositories i.e. despite the connect test failure you should be able to add your Mercurial repository to Fisheye and start indexing. The 60-second timeout is only imposed for connection testing.

Repository indexing is a different process and has a 60-minute timeout (default) as opposed to 60 seconds. Besides if the indexing process times out after 60 minutes (1 hour) it is possible to increase the timeout limits inside the repository configuration > SCM Details > Mercurial Options.
h3. Suggestion

I'd suggest changing the command we use to test connection to a Mercurial repository to something lighter and less error prone to avoid this problem. We could use {{hg identify -r 0}} instead of {{hg clone -r 0}}. The identify command will connect to the repository and get the commit number for the first changeset. This should be enough to test connection and make sure the user is able to access the repository without having to perform a test clone.
fields.summary: Change command used to test connection against Mercurial repositories

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If a single directory in a commit contains large number of files, rendering it in Fisheye can take significant amount of time and consume a lot of heap or even bring an instance down if max heap size is insufficient.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a commit with a large number of files in one directory (e.g. 100'000 or more).
 # Wait until the commit is indexed.
 # Open the directory in a repository browser in Fisheye.

h3. Expected Results

Content renders with no performance issues.
h3. Actual Results

High memory consumption. A heap dump may contain a huge char[] object containing rendered HTML of the tree content, including a text like:
{noformat}
<!-- Tree build time:<number> Node count:<number> --> 
{noformat}
as well as a lot of whitespace escaped as unicode ('\u000a' etc).
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behaviour. A workaround will be added here when available.

*Tips*

Try increasing max heap size.

Avoid commits containing hundreds of thousands of files. Split changes into smaller commits.
fields.summary: Loading large directory tree in a repository browser causes high heap consumption

fields.description:
Affected versions of Atlassian Dev Tools allow remote attackers 
 to browse local files via an Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR) vulnerability in WEB-INF in Fisheye/Crucible.

The affected versions are before version 4.8.5.

 

*Affected versions:*
 * version < 4.8.5

*Fixed versions:*
 * 4.8.5
 * 4.9.0
fields.summary: Local file disclosure / path traversal within WEB-INF in Crucible - CVE-2020-29446
Add Support for Google's "Repo" formated repositories

h3. Workaround

A possible workaround would be to select the option that Fisheye creates the SSH key pair: 
*  !image-2020-10-07-17-37-03-175.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: As a Fecru administrator, trying to upload a passphrase less SSH key throws an error: The request was rejected because its size: 0 KB, exceeds the maximum

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The SSH key upload for adding a new repository got rejected. The SSH key file was rejected as Fisheye expects SSH file size below 0 KB.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new repository as guided in [Git repository to Fisheye|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/setting-up-a-git-repository-in-crucible-298977505.html#SettingupaGitrepositoryinCrucible-Gitrepositorieshostedelsewhere] document.
 # After the third step, choose the *Git Authentication* as *Upload private key for ssh*
 # Upload the key from the local directory.

!Fisheye and Crucible_ Administration.gif!
h3. Expected Results

The key uploaded successfully and complete the wizard.
h3. Actual Results

!CRC-13762_bug.png|thumbnail!

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-fisheye-2020-MM-DD.log file:
{noformat}

h3. Workarounds
 # Use other [Authentication styles|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/authentication-960155500.html] such as:
 ** {{*Generate key pair for ssh*}}, in which case Fisheye will create the key pair and offer the user the public key, then configure the public key in the Git repository server
 ** {{*Password for http(s)*}}, if SSH is not needed.
 # If the problem has started after *upgrading* Fisheye to 4.8.4 (i.e., if 4.8.4 is *not* the first version ever installed of Fisheye), rollback to the version being used before the upgrade by restoring the most recent [backup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/backing-up-and-restoring-fisheye-data-960155610.html], then upgrade to 4.8.3 at the most because this problem does not happen in 4.8.3.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Fisheye 4.8.4 bundles new Jetty libraries version 9.4.30, and when a wildcard certificate is used the application fails to start.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Make sure to be using Fisheye 4.8.4 configured to use a wildcard certificate
 # Try starting the application

h3. Expected Results

Fisheye should be able to read the wildcard certificate.
h3. Actual Results

fields.description:
h3. Feature Summary

Display repository connection issues in the  Log Analyzer window.
h3. Current status

Currently, Log Analyzer catches only those errors, that are already described in KB articles at [https://confluence.atlassian.com|https://confluence.atlassian.com/]. However, if a repository connection error is recorded in the logs, it's not listed as a problem by Log Analyzer.
 The only place the error is known is the repositories state. However, this doesn't count the number of error occurrences so intermittent issues are not shown if not caught 'live'.
fields.summary: Include repository connection errors in the Log Analyzer report

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Sometimes when setting up a new Fisheye instance with Wizard my.atlassian.com doesn't send me back to my Fisheye
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # start a fresh license
 # click generate license

h3. Expected Results

I am redirected back to my instance.
h3. Actual Results

I stay on my.atlassian.com

The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
...
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Copy the new license and hit back button until on the setup page, then paste license.
fields.summary: When setting up a new Fisheye instance on a Wizard generating new license sometimes doesn't work

fields.description:
When attempting to create a custom plugin, the following errors aree shown:
  
{code:java}
The following artifacts could not be resolved: colt:colt-without-hep:jar:1.2.0-atlassian-2, com.boilerbay:infinitydb:jar:3.0-atlassian-hosted
{code}
This error surfaces when attempting to create a custom plugin in Fisheye 4.8.x version. Previous Fisheye versions does not have issues to create custom plugins.


h2. Workarounds

h3. Workaround #1

Build plugin with 4.7.0 version

h3. Workaround #2

Set 'provided' scope for infinitydb.
Install colt-without-hep locally using JAR from /lib folder and pom.xml below:

{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd" xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
    <groupId>colt</groupId>
    <artifactId>colt-without-hep</artifactId>
    <version>1.2.0-atlassian-2</version>
    <licenses>
        <license>
            <url>https://dst.lbl.gov/ACSSoftware/colt/license.html</url>
            <comments>It is a repack of cern colt project without hep.aida.* packages, which have license restrictions.</comments>
        </license>
    </licenses>
    <dependencies>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>concurrent</groupId>
            <artifactId>concurrent</artifactId>
            <version>1.3.4</version>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>
</project>
{code}
fields.summary: Cannot create custom Plugins on Fisheye 4.8.0+

fields.description:
It would be nice if we could get Fisheye and Crucible license details from the REST API (e.g. expiry date) similar to the way Jira displays this information under the following REST endpoint:
 * /rest/plugins/applications/1.0/installed/jira-software/license

At the moment this information is available through the UI (from the */admin/sysinfo.do* page) or inside the log files under *<FISHEYE_INST>/var/log* (during the startup process license details are printed to the logs).
fields.summary: Add REST endpoint to check license details

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The document [Connecting to Jira for user management - 2. Setup Fisheye to connect to Jira|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/connecting-to-jira-for-user-management-960155582.html#ConnectingtoJiraforusermanagement-2.SetupFisheyetoconnecttoJira], in step #2 states the following:
{quote}_"In the Fisheye administration area click *User Directories* (under 'Accounts')."_
{quote}
There is no 'Accounts' section in Fisheye administration area. The User Directories link is found under 'User Settings' section instead.
h3. Suggested Solution

The word 'Accounts' needs to be replaced by 'User Settings' in [our documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/connecting-to-jira-for-user-management-960155582.html#ConnectingtoJiraforusermanagement-2.SetupFisheyetoconnecttoJira].
h3. Workaround

Search for *User Directories* under 'User Settings' instead in the administration panel.
fields.summary: Replace 'Accounts' by 'User Settings' in the documentation

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When the Administration Panel is accessed anonymously by typing just the Administration Page password (i.e., without being logged in with any Fisheye user, being it admin or not), some pages keep reloading indefinitely and some will redirect to the user login screen, while other pages from the Administration Panel can be accessed without any problems.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Please watch the screen recording attached to this ticket. As can be seen:
 # Make sure to be accessing the Administration Panel totally anonymously, by just typing the Administration Page password.
 # Go to *System Settings > Find New Add-ons* and notice that the page will keep reloading indefinitely.
 # Go to *System Settings > Manage Add-ons* and notice that the page will keep reloading indefinitely.
 # Go to *System Settings > Troubleshooting and support tools* and notice that you will be redirected to the user login screen.
 # Login with a *regular user* (i.e., not administrator) and you will be able to access the same pages mentioned above because now there is a user logged in and the temporary anonymous administration session is still active. 

h3. Expected Results
 * The pages *Find New Add-ons* and *Manage Add-ons* should either redirect to the login screen (so as to have the same behavior as when the *Troubleshooting and support tools* link is clicked), or better, allow the completely anonymous session to access them and install / manage apps.
 * The *Troubleshooting and support tools* link should allow the completely anonymous session to access it and create support zips, etc.
 * The behavior should be the same in any page from the Administration Panel (e.g., *System Settings > Database* and *System Settings > Backup* can be accessed without any problems when just the Administration Page password is used). 

h3. Actual Results

No errors or warnings are written in the application logs, but the behaviors reported in the *Steps to Reproduce* happen.
h3. Workaround

Make sure to either:
 * Be logged in with a regular Fisheye user and also type the Administration Page password, or
 * Be logged in with a Fisheye user granted administrator permission, in which case the Administration Page password is not necessary.
fields.summary: Accessing some administration pages results in infinite reloads or in redirection to the login screen if not logged in

fields.description:
Affected versions of Atlassian FishEye allow remote attackers to view the HTTP password of a repository via an Information Disclosure vulnerability in the logging feature.

*Affected versions:*
 * version < 4.8.3

*Fixed versions:*
 * 4.8.3
 * 4.9.0
fields.summary: Information disclosure of repository HTTP password in logs - CVE-2017-18112

fields.description:
Hi Team,

This is regarding the ticket raised under Atlassian support PS-61114.

We have around 1050+ repositories in our Fisheye Crucible server instance. We have integrated our Fisheye instance with our Gerrit and SVN aaplications. The changeset replication in the instance is too bad now. Atlassian has commented like this is expected, due to the huge count of repositories. The incremental indexing is taking 1.5+ hours to replicate new changesets. Even tuning the fisheye performance is not having any considerable impact.

 

We need faster replication in some of our Git repositories and Atlassian suggested to [Configuring commit hooks|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/configuring-commit-hooks-960155647.html]. But there is no option available to configure commit hooks from our Gerrit server. Please consider this as a feature request and help us to improve the application performance and to introduce alternative ways to configure individual repository wise analysis and incremental indexing management.
fields.summary: Very slow replication of Changesets in Fisheye Crucible and no option for configuring commit hooks from Gerrit server

fields.description:
The https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/fisheye
and https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/crucible are official Atlassian images. 

However, applications in these images are exposed on port 8080, while the standard port is 8060.

Change it to 8060 to be consistent with standard installers.
fields.summary: Change Fisheye/Crucible port to 8060 in Atlassian's docker images

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a JavaHL native library is configured in Fisheye and a Subversion repository is being indexed on Windows, then:

 * the application log contains many 'Unable to delete file' entries and 
 * the temporary directory for a given repository (C:\Atlassian\Data\fecru\var\tmp\<repository-name>) contains temporary files, which have not been deleted

The problem does not occur when the bundled SVNKit Java client is used.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

 # Install Fisheye on Windows
 # Set up JavaHL native client for Subversion (could be any of WanDiso, CollabNet or other)
 # Index a Subversion repository

h3. Expected Results

Indexing proceeds with no errors in the logs.

h3. Actual Results

The below warnings are logged in the atlassian-fisheye.log file:

{noformat}
2020-03-23 07:21:40,048 WARN [InitPing1 repository ] fisheye IOHelper-deleteFile - Unable to delete file: C:\Atlassian\Data\fecru\var\tmp\repository\FESVNW_5129434092631388733
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: Indexing a Subversion repository with native JavaHL library logs 'Unable to delete file' warnings

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Use Fisheye 4.8.2 with the bundled SVNKit library
 # Add a repository using file:// protocol in the URL

h3. Expected Results
That message should not be written into the logs.

h3. Actual Results

That message is repeatedly written in the logs. 
The repository is indexed anyway.

h3. Workaround
# Open {{<Fisheye installation directory>/log4j.xml}}
# Find {{svnkit-fsfs}} logger
# Change the logger level from ...
{code:xml}
    <logger name="svnkit-fsfs">
        <level value="info"/>
    </logger>
{code}
... to ...
{code:xml}
    <logger name="svnkit-fsfs">
        <level value="error"/>
    </logger>
{code}
# Restart Fisheye

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Users created with uppercase usernames cannot un-follow a user.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user with uppercase username.
# Login with the newly created user
# Navigate to a repository->Activity->Click Username with activity
# Follow the user by clicking on the star

h3. Actual Results
An error pops up _"User 'MYFISH' isn't owner of the star with id 25"_ as shown in the image below:

Looking into the database, the record was saved as _lowercase_:
{code:sql}
select * from cru_base_star_model where cru_user_name='myfish'
{code}

h3. Expected Results
User should un-follow with no errors.


h3. Workaround
Delete the follow record from the database:
{code:sql}
delete from cru_base_star_model where cru_star_id=25
{code}
fields.summary: Users created with uppercase usernames cannot un-follow a user.

fields.summary: Problem with AWT on Windows - ImageWriterSpi is not initialised (images are not rendered)

fields.description:
The {{<fisheye installation>/python/hg/hgfelog/hgfelog.py}} script implements 'felog' command for Mercurial and is being used by Fisheye for indexing of Mercurial repositories.

Developed by Atlassian, since ~2010 it was published under the GPL v3 license.

This GPL license will be removed and since Fisheye/Crucible *4.8.3* the {{hgfelog.py}} script will be published under standard [Atlassian Software License Agreement|https://www.atlassian.com/legal/software-license-agreement], like the entire Fisheye & Crucible products.
fields.summary: Remove GPL v3 license from hgfelog.py script

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Smart commit parses all the Jira issue regex pattern and converts them to hyperlink linking to Jira and this also impacting the #comment by removing the hyperlink in Jira issue key's comment.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Integrate Fisheye ver4.8.0 and Jira ver8.5.1. Enable smart commit and application authorisation. 
# Add a git repository.
# On the terminal make changes and make a commit:
{code:java}
git commit -m "Terminal to Fisheye then to Jira TBFJ-1 #comment Alter to use gcc-10 instead of gcc-9 in SeeSim pipeline."
{code}
# Push to the remote git repository.

h3. Expected Results
To be able to see the complete message.
  !fisheye-jira-sm_issue-01.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Actual Results
The comment is incomplete.
  !fisheye-jira-sm_issue-02.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Smart commit parser isn't able to handle multiple issue key in commit messages

fields.description:
The bundled version of Atlassian Navigator Links plugin in Atlassian Fisheye before version 4.8.2 allows remote attackers to enumerate all linked applications, including those that are restricted or otherwise hidden, through an incorrect authorization check. Additional details about the issue in the Atlassian Navigator Links plugin can be found below.


The CustomAppsRestResource list resource in Atlassian Navigator Links before version 3.3.23, from version 4.0.0 before version 4.3.7, from version 5.0.0 before 5.0.1, and from version 5.1.0 before 5.1.1 allows remote attackers to enumerate all linked applications, including those that are restricted or otherwise hidden, through an incorrect authorization check.
fields.summary: The bundled version of Atlassian Navigator Links contained an incorrect authorization check  - CVE-2020-4026

fields.description:
The review coverage resource in Atlassian Fisheye and Crucible before version 4.8.2 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or Javascript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability through the committerFilter parameter.


*Affected versions:*
 * version < 4.8.2

*Fixed versions:*
 * 4.8.2
 * 4.9.0
fields.summary: XSS in the review coverage resource through the committerFilter parameter- CVE-2020-4023

fields.description:
We need to change the documentation of Fisheye regarding Access Logs. Some changes were introduced in Fisheye 4.7.x including the Jetty 9.4 version, which changed the way to configure additional logs settings.

We already have changed the documentation in 4.7 version (as you can see [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye047/enabling-access-logging-in-fisheye-981149785.html]), and we need to keep it in the subsequent Fisheye documents (such as [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/enabling-access-logging-in-fisheye-960155663.html]).

The https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/enabling-access-logging-in-fisheye-960155663.html document is outdated, it needs to be changed according to 4.7 version.
fields.summary: Update documentation regarding Fisheye Access Logs

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The old JavaMail 1.4 jar must use TLS 1.0 or 1.1, as can be seen [here|https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58638567/which-version-of-tls-is-supported-by-javamail-1-4].

The problem is that most companies have disabled TLS 1.0 and 1.1 for well known security problems.

Adding {{-Dmail.smtp.ssl.protocols=TLS1.2}} to {{FISHEYE_OPTS}} environment variable does not help because emails stop being sent by Fisheye.

h3. Suggested Solution
Update JavaMail library to at least 1.6 because this version already supports TLS 1.2

h3. Workaround
# Download [JavaMail 1.6.2|https://javaee.github.io/javamail/#Download_JavaMail_Release]
# Stop Fisheye
# Move {{<Fisheye Installation Directory>/lib/mail-1.4.jar}} to somewhere outside of Fisheye, as a backup
# Place JavaMail 1.6 at {{<Fisheye Installation Directory>/lib}}
# Start Fisheye
fields.summary: Update JavaMail library from 1.4 to 1.6 in order to support TLS 1.2

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently there are two documents for the same purpose:
- [Native Subversion Client|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/native-subversion-client-960155493.html]
- [Native support for SVN|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/native-support-for-svn-960155253.html]

h3. Suggested Solution
To avoid confusion and miscommunication these two documents should be merged into one, so that  the other one could be discarded.

h3. Workaround
Follow the steps from one of the documents above.
fields.summary: Merge two similar documents for Native SVN Client

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The [Fisheye SSL configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/fisheye-ssl-configuration-960155669.html] document is confusing because the steps mention different certificate aliases. Sometimes "fisheye" is mentioned, while sometimes "jetty" is mentioned.

h3. Suggested Solution
Unify different alias names into one.

h3. Workaround
Customers need to choose an alias name and continue using that alias while following all steps from the document.
fields.summary: Fisheye SSL configuration should mention a single cert alias

fields.description:
According to [this page|https://www.mysql.com/support/supportedplatforms/database.html], MySQL 5.6 is no longer supported on many platforms.

End support for this version of the database in Fisheye 4.9 (it will be no longer supported). Older versions of Fisheye will support this database version till [their end of life|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-support-end-of-life-policy-201851003.html].
fields.summary: End support for MySQL 5.6

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The following documentation [Configuring Jira integration in the Setup Wizard|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/configuring-jira-integration-in-the-setup-wizard-960155282.html] is not valid for integrating with Jira 7 + (and thus for supported FIsheye versions.

Specifically, the first line:
Configure the following setting in the Jira application: Allow remote API access.

Jira does not have that option anymore: [JRASERVER\-45768: Remove Accept remote API calls option from Configuring JIRA application options documentation|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-45768]

Suggested workaround: Remove the first line, and update the screenshot of the wizard.
fields.summary: Documentation on integrating Fisheye with Jira with the setup wizard is referencing old Jira version procedure
